comments.body: Not sure if it is worth creating a file. types.go is filled with many constants already.

when used within a podspec, this doesn't make sense... this is what I was saying about needing on StorageOSVolumeSource struct within a pod spec which used a LocalObjectReference for the secret, and an almost identical StorageOSPersistentVolumeSource struct within a PV spec which used an ObjectReference
I think I understand now: In types.go I create a StorageOSPersistentVolumeSource (1st plugin to do this) and use it in Provision() when returning the PV spec?

right, it's a very slightly different type than is used in a pod spec volume. It has ripples into the volume plugin, since it means there are two flavors of storageos volume sources :-/

that's one reason I wanted to get an opinion from @kubernetes/sig-storage-api-reviews on this
`+optional`
Done.
If this is required indicate so in the Godoc.  Also use the form where you include the external name (`ports`) in the Godoc.
It is required for WebSockets and optional for SPDY.
What's the default for SPDY?  Basically any question someone would have about this field should be answered by the godoc in our default style so it shows up in docs.

SPDY expects the port information as a HTTP Header.
This is where backward compatibility and the capabilities of the transports do not translate well. SPDY which was already there passed the Ports as a HEADER in the request(s). SPDY allows multiple requests.
Websockets does not allow HEADERs to be set so it had to be ports in a query parameter.

To my knowledge there is no way to document the HEADER as part of the API and that is what is there today.

Expand the godoc for this field and for the type that a consumer using them would have some indication of what they are doing and how it is used.  You should comment that this field is not used when the SPDY protocol is invoked in protocol versions up to the current one (the docs for port forward should be declaring a protocol number, if not, say that the first SPDY protocol version does not support port forward).
AutomountServiceAccountToken, 21, is not part of staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/pkg/api/v1/types.go.

This is wrong - this should have been `schedulerName`

Please ensure this is fixed pre 1.6.0 - this is a release blocker.
sure, I'll create a PR today :).
same comment re: decoration

Hmm. We'd need to extend strategic merge patch in order to support this properly. We definitely want automated processes to be able to add additional configmaps (#17097).

One alternative would be to not use the OneOf pattern in EnvFromSource and instead include an object reference that would specify the resource type (kind and apiVersion). Another alternative would be to use separate arrays for configmaps, secrets, services, and any types we add in the future that would define multiple environment variables. The former sounds less objectionable.

Any other ideas @pwittrock?
@mbohlool Should we have `// +optional` here?
Same question for `pkg/api/types.go`
Thanks!

comments.body: Usually, there's also `LastProbeTime unversioned.Time` which is the last time a check was actually performed. See [PodCondition](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/42e5f95a6b41877a56f909e06aef912f63948eaa/pkg/api/types.go#L1233) or [JobCondition](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/42e5f95a6b41877a56f909e06aef912f63948eaa/pkg/apis/batch/types.go#L159).

But does `LastProbeTime` make sense for the types of conditions we have for replica sets? Both `Ready` and `ReplicaFailure` conditions are updated only once their status changes. See https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/19343#r50511982 for more info on this.
That comment and further discussion doesn't convince me to have just single timestamp. Having both seems more flexible, imho.
Updated with both types of timestamps
Just one condition? What about running or similar, at least?
I can add an additional `Ready` condition type.
I'm not convinced Ready is meaningful for an RC.
can you add something to validation_test.go that tests with this limit type?
what happens if not specified?
according this [MSDN note](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn495144.aspx), `None` is the default if not set.
I think this needs to be `0755`, because the execute bit is needed to recurse directory trees if you don't own them.
At least, directories need the execute bit set.  That's important to communicate.
No, this setting doesn't affect directories, just files. Directories are created the same way as before (execute bit is there IIRC)
Tag 4 is correct (note to other reviewers) since this is a net new field in proto.
This doesn't tell me what sort of value goes here.  Is it a random number?  The name of a Kubernetes Service?  A URL?  Some key from a different API?
it's a host port pair (or multiple host port pairs separated by commas". The host can be an IP address or a DNS name and the port must be the Quobyte API Port (default: 7861).
This is fully backwards compatible, right?
@roberthbailey It will change patch and apply behavior for this resource, though the current behavior is unusable.
If someone did manage to workaround this problem and was using strategic merge patch, their patches should still work.
thanks.
This is probably ok.
Failed pods aren't restarted by Kubelet. Only failed containers are.
This is probably just going to be a proposal to avoid undue iteration here.
We've been bit several times by unsupported fields, so if we go with this approach, we should create a more specific container type that omits those fields.

The more specific type (when so many fields are the same) may end up
being worse for both internal clarity and clients.  We can validate
unsupported fields easily, but it's much harder to deal with two very
similar types with the same code / logical structure.
Just make this "cannot currently be added, removed or updated"
So they're not like "normal" containers because I can't update the image on a crashlooping container, right? I guess the comment say immutable, but I still expected the same image update caveat.

I mostly wanted to avoid having to tear down all subsequent init containers
and all app containers in the event of a change.  Today it only tears down
the container.  I'll leave a follow on in the proposal?

On Wed, May 4, 2016 at 10:23 PM, Prashanth B notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In pkg/api/v1/types.go
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/23567#discussion_r62142668
> :
> 
> >  // PodSpec is a description of a pod.
> >  type PodSpec struct {
> >     // List of volumes that can be mounted by containers belonging to the pod.
> >     // More info: http://releases.k8s.io/HEAD/docs/user-guide/volumes.md
> >     Volumes []Volume `json:"volumes,omitempty" patchStrategy:"merge" patchMergeKey:"name" protobuf:"bytes,1,rep,name=volumes"`
> > -   // List of initialization containers belonging to the pod.
> > -   // Init containers are executed in order prior to containers being started. If any
> > -   // init container fails, the pod is considered to have failed and is handled according
> > -   // to its restartPolicy. The name for an init container or normal container must be
> > -   // unique among all containers.
> > -   // Init containers may not have Lifecycle actions, Readiness probes, or Liveness probes.
> > -   // The resourceRequirements of an init container are taken into account during scheduling
> > -   // by finding the highest request/limit for each resource type, and then using the max of
> > -   // of that value or the sum of the normal containers. Limits are applied to init containers
> > -   // in a similar fashion.
> > -   // Init containers cannot currently be added or removed.
> > -   // Init containers are in alpha state and may change without notice.
> > -   // Cannot be updated.
> 
> So they're not like "normal" containers because I can't update the image
> on a crashlooping container, right? I guess the comment say immutable, but
> I still expected the same image update caveat.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/23567/files/fabc8f18ac2996f19fe403b2be7d42bf0f8f8849#r62142668

Actually - it depends :)
Basically, for generating client we use "second closest comment line", but e.g. for protobuf generation we are using the main comment, e.g.:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/api/unversioned/time.go#L30

And for member fields we don't have SecondClosestComment lines yet.

I've added a TODO and will fix that in a separate PR (this is just a single place for now, so shouldn't cause big user problems :))

Yes, it means only perform the operation if the named object has the given UID.

RV precondition is trivial to add later, but I don't think it's nearly as useful as a UID precondition.
Hmm - what's the purpose of checking if object has a given UID? Can you please give me one usecase for it? Is it supposed to check if this isn't a new object recreated after previous deletion?

> Is it supposed to check if this isn't a new object recreated after previous deletion?

Yes.

Alternatively we can use RV as a precondition, but that has false negative. For example, when a user tries to delete an object, but the object is updated by another party, the deletion fails.

OK - thanks (I agree that RV is not good for this purpose - it's good for other purposes, e.g. change my object assuming that a different object didn't change since my computation (=has a given RV)). This was widely used pattern in Omega.

Yeah, we do check RV in the Update path, but that RV is extracted from the new object sent by the user, not from an "UpdateOptions". As lavalamp commented, it should be straight-forward if we want to add RV to Preconditions later :)
Yeah - but I meant preconditions of RV of other objects (not the one that we are updating). This is something that you cannot currently do. But sure - we can add it later.

I would need to see a use case for that, it sounds complicated.

This seems like it should be called `AzureFileService` and the volume source should be called `AzureFileServiceVolumeSource`
This comment is not sufficient for me.  What is an interface here?  Can you be clearer on what this is doing?

You can refer to the the [open-iscsi documentation Section 5.1.1](http://www.open-iscsi.org/docs/README), the [openstack documentation](http://docs.openstack.org/kilo/config-reference/content/iscsi-iface-config.html). An open-iscsi interface is at minimum a 3-tuple of transport name, iface name and hardware address (MAC) that will direct iscsi traffic over a particular HBA/network interface/offload driver instead of going over the default network interface.
Cite references if you must, but our docs need to be usable
The changes to the README already provides this information and more as well as links to configuration docs
Can we change this name to "severity"?
I guess this name was @bgrant0607's idea-- I still think "type" is an ambiguous name.

It's intentionally ambiguous. I don't want this to evolve in the direct of log severity levels, which are very hard to use in my experience. It's just a coarse bucketing of Reasons along some useful dimensions, TBD. Like Reason, it shouldn't be considered to be an enum.

The Real Solution to filtering is something like separately defined alerting rules.

I see your point about severity levels. I agree external filtering/alerting is the way to go, and is in fact what I wanted events to go into all along, but no time :(

I tend to think that it'd be better without type at all, considering the above. I don't see how local determinations of normal vs warn can be reliably made.

Does that mean you're agreeing with the feedback and have not update this PR or arguing with the feedback?  I can't tell... :)

@thockin It means I'm agreeing, but I'm building on top of this PR.  I'm fine with squashing into a single commit once `PodSecurityContext` has at least one field in the v1 API, but I really want to make some progress on what we're going to build on top of the commit in this PR.

How can this value be in the future? Validation will complain if this is less than 1s so I guess this comment is redundant.
The time the client thinks is the future and the time the user thinks is the future and the time the node and container think is the future can all differ.

Since pkg/expapi is not yet ready, an alternative would be to leave these types where they are for now, but not expose them in master yet. I think that will be sufficient for them to not show up in documentation. When pkg/expapi is ready, we'd move them.

You're planning to implement this default in a subsequent PR? (That's fine, just asking whether it was an oversight or deliberate.)
Deliberately planning on implementing that separately,  I want the dust to settle on the objects/design before I spend time implementing things.
Do we really need the leading dot?
And why is DockerConfigKey != SecretTypeDockercfg?

> Do we really need the leading dot?

The leading dot matches the current, default filename exactly.  It makes it very convenient to directly bundle a secret from an existing file and means less transformation if a pod wants to mount it and use it as is.

> And why is DockerConfigKey != SecretTypeDockercfg?

Because I don't like leading dots?  I like having the secret type qualified by "kubernetes.io" like `SecretTypeServiceAccountToken`, but I don't feel very strongly past that.  If you prefer "kubernetes.io/.dockercfg", I'm willing to change it, but I think it's more prone to typos.
After skimming the docs and examples, I get it now.
@bgrant0607 do we want to put a deprecated field into the v1 api?
Yes. We'll rip it out when we rip out the beta API versions.
after reading this I have even less idea what to put here than I did before.

comments.body: These changes are because I copied v1beta3 to v1 again, so this now includes changes to v1beta3 that happened while https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/pull/7454 was in review.
